body:
good idea! I'll add the "good first issue" tag, since it seems to be a more or less straightforward case of "fill out the [extension template](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/extension_templates/forecasting.py)"?

Contributions welcome.

rename.from: Request for LinkedIn Greykite time series model

body: This might be a trivial question, but how does interfacing works? Do we have to import grey kite libraries and fill the extension template or understand the algorithm and then fill the template? @fkiraly @surajitdb
@Aparna-Sakshi yes you can follow the extension template. We would have to import it as a soft-dependency. How to do this, you can look into how we did it for `fbprophet` or `tbats`.
@aiwalter Thanks a lot for the info, I'll look into it.

Yes, exactly.

I've turned the observation that there are currently no explicit instructions about soft dependencies into an issue to add this in all extension templates. https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1759
You may or may not want to do this on the side, if you are looking into this, @Aparna-Sakshi.

If you need some inspiration for the code, given the unusual Greykite API, you can draw it from [here](https://github.com/winedarksea/AutoTS/blob/master/autots/models/greykite.py): winedarksea already implemented it in their AutoTS library.

hm, AutoTS looks a bit like a `pycaret` clone?
But could be a good starting point to what the parameters are etc.

What do you think, @ngupta23?

AutoTS and Auto_TS came before pycaret time series module. 

AutoTS seems to combine the functionality of sktime and pycaret into a single library (something similar to what Auto_TS also does). 

Also it seems to be using genetic algorithms to find the best models. PyCaret uses random and grid  hyperparameter tuning (adopted from sktime). Having Bayesian hyperparameter optimization as a next step might be good.

Does AutoTS provide the ability to hand craft the individual models if the automated workflow is not desired? I think that kind of flexibility is needed as not everyone is comfortable with a fully automated workflow.

got it - so the takeaway is, do I understand correctly:
* autoTS predates pycaret-ts (but not pycaret?), the user facing designs are similar
* but itÂ´s not similar in terms of the the internal layers interface: autoTS does not separate between the "composition/specification" layer and the "workflow/deployment" layer. Whereas pycaret builds on sktime as a flexible layer.
* nonetheless, in how autoTS interfaces greykite (the "specific model" layer), we can learn for sktime. In a sense, we need to move the greykite wrapper "a layer lower" (to the composable interface, where it belongs).

> autoTS predates pycaret-ts (but not pycaret?), the user facing designs are similar

I have not delved much into it, but the focus of `autoTS` seems to be on the "auto" part. Whereas in `pycaret`, the users can customize their workflows for both **manual** (create specific models) and **automated** (pick best from all) approaches. On the other hand, pycaret does not support multivariate but autoTS does. So there might be pros and cons of both libraries.

> nonetheless, in how autoTS interfaces greykite (the "specific model" layer), we can learn for sktime

Yes, I think that is correct.
@fkiraly It might be interesting to see how **holidays** are handled in `sktime`. Is there an example for how `sktime` does this for `prophet`?
